The mandatory code assignments will include starter code that you will work with to complete the assignment. This means that the repository will include code that you will update, based on the instructions provided.

For each assignment, take time to read all instructions and requirements provided for the assignment. If there are instructions that you do not understand, contact an instructor or teaching assistant for clarification.

Once you understand what is expected, take time to plan out the code, using flowcharts, pseudocode, class diagrams, or ERDs as appropriate for the activity. This will help you define what you want the code to do and make the time you spend writing code more efficient. You may be asked to provide this documentation for some assignments.

When you start to code, write the code incrementally and run it after each step. Running the code frequently will make it easier to identify and pinpoint errors as you work and correct those errors before starting the next increment of code.

⚠ Important!

Each GitHub Classroom code assignment will contain at least one file. Do not change or delete any existing files unless instructed to do so.

Where you are expected to change an existing file, the assignment instructions will clearly state which file or files you are expected to update.

Click the link provided by the instructor or in the assignment instruction and authorize GitHub Classroom to access your account, if prompted to do so.

GitHub Classroom will then prompt you to accept the assignment.

Click the button to accept the assignment and then wait for the repo to be configured. This process typically takes 2–3 minutes.

After a couple of minutes, refresh the page to check the status, using the Refresh button in the browser toolbar or a shortcut key like Ctrl-R. When the repository is ready, you will see a link to the new repository.

The link is unique to your account and should include your GitHub username at the end of the URL.

Click the link to open the repository and view the starter files.

Clone the repository to a local folder. Instructions for cloning a repository are provided elsewhere in this course.

Once the repository has been cloned to your computer, open the project folder in your preferred IDE (such as NetBeans or IntelliJ). Take time to examine the existing files, but do not change any file except as specified in the assignment instructions.

You are encouraged to commit frequently as you work on the assignment. Each time you commit, use a commit message like commit1, commit2, commit3, etc., incrementing as you go. The number of commits is not important, and there is no maximum number of allowed commits.

Checking Your Work

The code assignments that start with a template repository include unit tests that will check your code each time you commit the code. The exact number of tests depends on the complexity of the program, but they will usually range between 3-5 tests.

⚠ Your code must pass all tests by the specified due date and time for you to receive credit for your work.

You can run the tests in two different ways:

  1. Use your IDE (NetBeans or IntelliJ) to run the unit tests in the IDE.
  2. Push updates to the code to GitHub.

Failing tests will not count against you during the development process. You are encouraged to run tests frequently to check your progress, and it is expected that tests will fail until you complete all parts of the assignment.

This lesson shows a few options for running these tests and viewing the results. These are not the only ways to complete this task! If you are already familiar with another way to run and check unit tests, you are welcome to use that process instead of using the steps shown here.

Select your IDE to see details on how to run the unit tests.

NetBeans

Open the Project

Open the project folder in NetBeans.

Build the Project

Build the project as soon as it opens. This will add in all of the dependencies identified by Maven and run all tests included in the project. The tests will fail at this point, but it gives you a starting point to work from.

⚠ Important

The starter code should run without errors. If the initial build reports errors in the code (except for failing tests), contact an instructor or teaching assistant immediately.

After the project has been built, you can view the test results in the Navigator pane at the bottom of the window, on the Output tab.

IntelliJ

Open the Project

Open the project folder in IntelliJ.

Build the Project

Build the project to update the Maven repositories and check for any errors in the code.

⚠ Important

The starter code should compile without errors. If the initial build reports errors in the code (except for failing tests), contact an instructor or teaching assistant immediately.

After building the code, run the code. IntelliJ will automatically run the tests that are included with the starter code, and the results of the tests will appear.

Right-click the file and click Run 'EmployeeSalaryCalculatorTest' (Ctrl+Shift+F10) in the context menu to run the tests.

The tests will run and the results will display in the bottom pane, with the tests in the left window and details about the tests in the right pane.

The details include the name of the test file and the line number where the test starts, along with what the resulting output should be based on each test. This example includes a main test file (EmployeeSalaryCalculatorTest) and two separate tests: testSalaryCalculator and testSalaryCalculator1. The status at the top of the pane also reads "Tests failed: 2 of 2 tests."

There may be more than two tests in other assignments.

Open the File to Edit

Review the instructions and find the file the instructions tell you to modify. In this example, we are using the EmployeeSalaryCalculator / src / main / EmployeeSalaryCalculator.java file.

Open the file in IntelliJ and find the code placeholders provided. Review the existing code to identify any variables or other code that already exists and that you will need to use in your solution, but remember that you should not change any existing code. All new code should be inside the placeholders provided.

In this example, the assignment asks us to add code to the if-else block. We'll start with the if clause.

Review the existing variables already declared in the class:

Because these variables already exist, we can use them in the methods without having to redeclare them.

We want to calculate the total salary by multiplying the number of hours worked (HW) by the hourly rate (HR). We can write an equation for that. Note that the existing method (SalaryCalculator) returns the variable GrossSalary, so we want to be sure that the result is saved to GrossSalary.

After updating the code, build the program again. This will check for errors in the code as well as run the tests again. Assuming the code is correct, the test panel will now show that one test passed and one test failed.

After verifying that the first test passes, use a similar approach to add code that passes the next test, using a different placeholder for new code.
